commentBody: Clever theme!
Got this one in max(d/dx displacement) for a Sunday.

Voting is now open for the 2024 Puzzle of the Year awards. Nominees are in four groups: Early Week (Monday‚ÄìWednesday), Thursday, Themeless (Friday & Saturday) and Sunday. As in years past, there will be two rounds of voting. In the first round, you may select up to five puzzles in each group. The five puzzles receiving the most votes will move on to the second round of voting. First round voting ends January 24. Here's the link to the ballot: https://form.jotform.com/243358842724059 Many thanks to everyone who nominated a puzzle. I don't think I missed any nominations, but if I did, let me know ASAP and I'll add it to them to the ballot. Thanks also to John Ezra and Cat Lady Margaret for their help with this project. If the third-party ballot doesn't work for some reason, blame me and not John or Margaret.

The math wasn‚Äôt hard, because each entry fit its clue so well. Fun!

Here‚Äôs what I got:

d/dt (tragedy + time)


DERIVATIVE COMEDY

Strangely, the integral sign ‚à´ was missing from my online clue for 99A ‚Äúworkout routine‚Äù, so I was a bit confused by that until reading the column. But I figured out the answer easily enough. 

SQUARED UP and ADDED COMPLEXITY are my favorites. Nice debut of DIFFERENCE OF OPINION. I‚Äôm surprised that has never appeared before. 

A clever theme and a solving experience that I enjoyed to the nth degree. 

Nicely done, Emily and Kunal.
Nice one. Not too hard. First time for pickleball mention??
I have so much admiration for folks who can make these incredible puzzles. I hope you pay them well!üòÅ

Chance = possiibility

EQUAL OPPORTUNITY

Deb was told there would be no math. 
Good thing Caitlin caught this one.

Lots of fun in the puzzle, 
and I'm also enjoying
the posters' themers!

Thanks, Emily and Kunal, ETAL.

Harsh Sound / Unifying Image = 

Grate (sic) Theme!
I just want to point out that HOTEL CALIFORNIA won in 1978, not 1976. ;)
83D took me right back to the Dip War of 4/20/24.
Easy but fun Sunday puzzle. And nice to see some representation with quite a few India-themed clues.

When it comes to calculus puns, I have my limit.

(Besides, they're pretty derivative.)

Fun solve and clever clues. I didn't know some of the math symbols but figured out the answers anyway. Since I print out a hard copy, and puzzles with any symbols or odd font things require a one-page PDF, it makes it very hard to see the tiny letters and faint symbols. I need to buy a magnifying glass!
I found this very arcane with references to things I never heard of. I walked away.
This was a lot of fun, well done!

We love to the print the puzzle  and leave it on the island in the kitchen.  Anyone cruising by is free to play.  Sadly, this one is just one page with very small print. and puzzle.  Is there any way you can make into a 2-page puzzle like previous ones?

Many thanks!
Straightforward
That was fun.  Wouldn‚Äôt say it was ‚Äúeasy‚Äù but very doable.  This is my favorite kind of math.

I enjoyed it, despite not exactly loving each of the"math" expressions.  The whole thing felt very easy, Tuesday / Wednesday level, but that's not a complaint.  I do kinda wish it lasted longer though.  Sundays shouldn't be QUITE this quick.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

As an ed. who works mostly with math-related mss, could you guys have not used a proper division symbol (√∑)?

Aside from that, fun solve!
Great fun, and a very entertaining theme. For me quite fast.

I don't know if there was a typo in the online version, or if my computer won't show the integral symbol, but my clue for 99A was just "workout routine." Maybe have the editors check the online version again?

Very frustrated that the Sunday crossword puzzle often will not print out as a large priint version.  I have tried to contact someone at NY Times but can't get to anyone who can fix the problem.  Can anyone gset through to them??!!  It means I cannot play a puzzle I have paid for.
I had a Natick at 12D/20A; had to run the alphabet; and of course had to get to 'Y' before the happy music.

I was just thinking today, and congratulating myself because I never look stuff up, except once a couple of years ago - do Americans really spell IDYLLS with just one L - thus IDYLS?  As a Brit resident here for 40 years, it's a word which has never come up AFAIK, and yes it really is spelled so in US English.
Nene is a Hawaiian goose. B√©be is a Spanish baby. Did the constructor mean something else?!
I can‚Äôt believe it! I have Pachinko right on my bedside table (I have yet to read it but now I‚Äôm definitely going to!). Absolute fate.
Really enjoyed this one. The theme wasn't too difficult to suss out but was still fun and the it was a good steady solve.
Why are women 35-44 remos?
Learned a bit about Indian history, geography and cooking in this one.

Fun theme but poor execution with too much junk (ASSAM, KARO, FAA, ESE, NENES, NGOS, AGA, RKO, MOS, IVE, ESO, SRA, SUPE, UFC, OPI, RAITA, ETTE, MSS, AGEE, OGEE) plus the dupe of LETUP and LETON.  Yuck.

A whopping 34(!) 3-letter words that were, for the most part, bad fill really soured the experience.  Plus the longer entries like ESOTERICA and SCIATACA just weren't that enjoyable.  More time should have been spent on grid construction/layout IMO.
Took me much too long to guess Raita and Assam,  but thoroughly enjoyed the references to Indian cuisine, geography and mythology.
I am mathematically challenged, so I ignored the signs and did the words.  Worked for me.

Another breezy puzzle, filled easily then the search for typos‚Ä¶.  Found three and was rewarded with a gold star!  Bested my Thursday average time so that hints to it being pretty easy for a larger puzzle.  I thought idyll had two l‚Äôs‚Ä¶
Turns out I have no idea how to spell Kilimanjaro ü§£

Caitlin, excellent video choice üëè. Mitchell and Webb are just the best!

Puzzle was enjoyable as well - nice work Emily and Kunal!

I count 65 acrosses and 76 downs.  

I'll ask the crossword gurus...isn't that a lot, even for a Sunday?
A first for me: being happy about getting SCIATICA

Nice puzzle. Straightforward Sunday early morning. 

Had to come here to understand DEMO but then again one doesn‚Äôt need to get everything. 

Natnicks, at least for this member of the international contingent, at AYO FROYO, DAN RAITA, and KARO PAOLO but they were all guessable. 

Thanks
The most amazing thing in this crossword is the notion that a dessert could be topped with Gummy Bears and chocolate chips. Oh, America!

I thought it took me a long time to solve this but apparently, this was 5:24 faster than my average. Yikes. I guess you could say me and my time had a DIFFERENCEOFOPINION.

No? No takers? I guess I'll stick to puzzle-solving then üòâ
The integral symbol didn‚Äôt appear in the iOS app.

Typical tough Saturday for me, and did have to cheat a bit in a couple of places. And... must confess that I wasn't entirely catching on to the trick in some of the theme answers. Had to go back and ponder after I was done, and even then was a bit unsure of a couple of them. No big deal; that's me. A quite unusual (and appropriate) puzzle find today. This one was also all in the clues (and some quite unusual answers). A Thursday from August 11, 2011 by Parker Lewis. Here are some sample theme clues and answers: "3, 6, 11, 18, 27 ... :" XSQUAREDPLUSTWO "4, 2, 4/3, 1, 4/5 ... :" TWENTYOVERFIVEX "8, 1, -18, -55, -116 ... :" NINEMINUSXCUBED And... the 'reveals' (both of them down answers): "Any of the clues for 17-, 34- or 57-Across :" SEQUENCE "In the answers to 17-, 34- and 57-Across, it was replaced in turn by 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ... :" VARIABLE One time math major here, but I'm quite sure my chances at that one would have been zero (appropriately). Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/11/2011&g=17&d=A I'll shut up now. ....
Fun and breezy. I was unaware that there was a person named Dapper DAN. This is what came to mind for me: https://ebay.com/itm/195544146440

For those who, like me, have trouble seeing the Sunday puzzle when it prints out on one page, I have two suggestions that will help in most cases.

1 - Buy a cheap set of readers to put over your glasses to increase  the power when needed.

or

2- Use a magnifying glass.

Don't curse the darkness.....

One look-up, of the unknown (to me) actor A_O crossing the unknown, and terrifying as clued, dessert FRO_O.

Hung up for a long time in the SE. IDYLS with one L was unknown to me, [Subtly indicate] isn't really close to the usage of LET ON that I'm familiar with, ELI as a shortened version of ELIjah was oddly difficult to arrive at ...

But did enjoy the theme, which gave me some long fills on otherwise flimsy evidence. If it hadn't been for those pesky cells in the SE, this would have been quite a fast one for me.

I finished this puzzle in less than half my usual time, but still got the ‚Äúalmost but not quite‚Äù message. Stared at the grid for what felt like an hour (it was 5 min) and even checked the answer key. 

I got hung up on JAM/JAR and didn‚Äôt notice. The devil is in the details. Streak broken!

Strands Thread.  Please, avoid spoilers until after the View All Replies button. 


Strands #322
‚ÄúI get the message‚Äù
üîµüîµüü°üîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ


Off my game this morning.

I love how this theme originated ‚Äì that Kunal has a habit of imagining phrases that contain a math word as math formulas, and thought, ‚ÄúMaybe there‚Äôs a theme here‚Ä¶‚Äù

Then he and Emily brainstormed and came up with enough theme answers (7) to make a Sunday puzzle out of it.

Stellar constructor Peter Gordon, who, with 130 NYT puzzles under his belt, ought to know, told me that 9 out of 10 theme ideas fall flat for lack of enough theme answers.

So, the goddess Fortuna smiled on Kunal and Emily today, providing sufficient answers, not to mention giving them the talent to find them and create perfecto clues for them.

Their grid contains ten NYT debut answers.  Debut answers can bring spark to the solve, giving solvers clues and answers they‚Äôve never encountered before.  They can also be dull and not contribute anything to the fill-in.  

Almost all of today‚Äôs are of the former type, IMO, my favorites being DIFFERENCE OF OPINION, SQUARED UP, GO TOO FAR, and, as clued, the exquisite IN A PAST LIFE.

And so, much fortune in the box today.  Congratulations on your first Sunday, Kunal, and your NYT puzzle debut Emily, and thank you so much for making this!
I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle.  It‚Äôs an amazing feat to construct clues to math symbols.  Kudos to you both for a fun puzzle!

One third faster than my average.  Loved the theme.

TIL: "The naked mole-rat (Heterocephalus glaber), also known as the sand puppy, is a burrowing rodent native to the Horn of Africa and parts of Kenya" (Wikipedia)

More often than not, a puzzle's theme is a nuisance to work around. But this puzzle's is GREAT! (Read in Tony the Tiger voice.) It's one of the rare ones that both entertains and facilitates solving. Rare for me, anyway. I'm not as sharp as I used to be. Very well done!

Somehow I made it through all the math classes I was ever required to take with passing or even decent grades. Mathematics is among the things that don‚Äôt engage me, except as it pertains to everyday life. I am more concerned with practical rather than theoretical stuff.

That being said, I did get the meaning of most of the themed clues. I solved the rest of the ‚Äúproblems‚Äù regardless. I thought this was a great puzzle in spite of its slant. It took a bit longer than average but I solved ABM.

If it weren‚Äôt for crossword puzzles, the IDYL spelling would go the way of the dodo. Or of aeternall. The only way it would move the Google Ngram Viewer needle would be when new editions of Tennyson‚Äôs ‚ÄòEnglish Idyls‚Äô were digitized. But here we are, celebrating its 99th appearance in the NYT. Noah Webster is doing cartwheels in his resting place. Unnecessary double Ls enjoyed a special place in his craw. 

Even Tennyson didn‚Äôt stay faithful to his IDYLS, He turned right around (we call it a UEY in common xword junk fill) and we got his ‚ÄòIDYLLS of the King‚Äô just a couple of decades later. You could say he got right, er, past oral influences. (Go ahead, groan away.)

Like all misguided things, we got IDYL from the French who, in the wild and orthographically crazy 17th c., spelled it as idyle instead of idylle, and for a couple hundred years IDYL was good enough. Blount‚Äôs and Phillips‚Äôs early English dictionaries in the 1650s gave us IDYL; Noah Webster gave us IDYL in 1806. But then the Victorians said, ‚ÄúOoh, Hellenism! What a bright and shiny thing.‚Äù And they trudged out the Greek eid≈≠ÃÅllƒ≠on to bring IDYL back to its classical roots. Tennyson was thus corrupted in 1858, and the OED published the fascicle with IDYLL in 1899. 

Noah would have disagreed. He thought silent letters superfluous. He said that if we were to honor Greek etymology, then we should have ‚Äúfyzzic, karacter, [and] korus.‚Äù

But crossword puzzles are keeping IDYL alive.

(Online puzzle platforms) X (more pop culture and brand names) X  (Gamified subscription model) =
THE TIMES THEY ARE A-CHANGIN‚Äô

Explain my answer?
Faster than average is the trend.

I liked math in school, but this - not so much.
On the plus side, I remembered the nail polish starts with O.
An obscure proper name cross ("ayo"/"assam"), a very obscure "imarets", plus when you start using Spanish slang ("nenes") all points to an unsatisfying puzzle.

I was great at simple arithmetic in elementary school, but high school math was a disaster for me. So when I saw all these math-related clues, I figured the puzzle was a no-go. Even though I never heard of the Pixar movie or the integral symbol, I managed to get them from the crosses. 

At end end of the day, or rather the beginning of the morning, it was a fairly easy puzzle, even though I don't think TOTS wear onesies, only infants. And those infants CHEESE all over whoever is feeding them, not get ticked off. I love RAITA (currently have 3 containers in the fridge), but never  had it with fried chickpea flour. That one was really easy to get from the crosses. And now I'm hungry for some froyo without the gummy bears.

absolutely LOVED the themed clues--so clever and so satisfying to solve! 

today took longer than average but not because of the themed clues, i got really stuck on the E/SE side for a while, i've never heard 59A before üò≠

i also can't figure out what 80D means, if someone could please explain i'd appreciate it!

Emily and Kunal, thank you. 

Brilliant puzzle, wickedly clever theme. First Sunday I‚Äôve solved without any hints or lookups. 

I‚Äôll tell ya what though, trying to spell KILIMANJARO without any crosses was a test of my memory that‚Äôs for sure.

Really enjoyed this one. A clever theme, well-executed, easily justified (to me) the fill needed to get it done. I like a theme that gives me an ‚Äúaha!‚Äù moment early on and helps me complete the rest of the theme set. In this case, once I had DIVISION OF from the crosses, I saw ‚Ä¶ LABOR right away and then had fun with the other themers. 

As a result, this was a rather quick solve although I got a bit stymied in the SW ‚Äî REP and SAC didn‚Äôt come readily, I still think CHEESED should have been clued as a Britishism (have never heard anyone say it on this side of the pond), and my initial purchase of an IpAd rather than an IMAC didn‚Äôt help. But I straightened that out soon enough. 

Thanks Emily and Kunal ‚Äî look forward to  the results of your next road trip!
This is the first Sunday puzzle I could complete without going to the hints. Enjoyed it!

Haven't been defeated by a Sunday puzzle in a long time. This one got me, though I have only myself to blame. Failed on FROYO/AYO, and I have a rather strong feeling that I also stumbled on FROYO the last time it appeared---fairly recently, not INAPASTLIFE. Got everything else, but my streak ended ... at 3. Failed this past Wednesday too. So I didn't even BREAK SEVEN.

Being a mathematician helped me get all the thematic entries rather easily. This was good, because filling the rest of the grid was a rather unpleasant struggle for me. Perhaps the falling pressure from the impending snowstorm has affected my brain, but solving this one was like pulling (my own) teeth.

At least I learned/reviewed some Indian geography and cuisine.

"Sitter's charge" for PET (and not FEE) was cute. Didn't like "Soft rock" for TALC, but that's just me. Talc is a mineral, the predominant one in the soft rock typically called soapstone. That said, of course I entered TALC instantly upon reading the clue.

I wonder, has POLARVORTEX made its appearance in a NYT puzzle yet? Stay warm.

So glad to see Mr. Shortz listed as editor! I hope this is a sign he is feels well!

I haven‚Äôt done the puzzle yet, busy getting ready for our first big storm!
Nice smooth solve. Theme answers accessible for non math people..except the SW was tricky for me...

Fun solve and clever theme. Thank you!
Almost nailed it with a personal best time were it not for a typo while attempting to "Fard" the river at 70D.

Excellent puzzle, many thanks to Emily and Kunal!
The themed entries were satisfying to work out with just a few crossing letters. Wonderfully clever clues and entries.

My favourite Martin Van Buren fact: he was the first US president born in the United States of America

There are frequent questions posted here that can be answered by a quick query on xwordino.com

I want to remind everyone that for a mere $20 per year you can sign up and support the invaluable work that Jim Horne does.
Nicely built and provided a good mix of ironic chuckles, aha moments, and new vocab. Pushed my 2025 average up 4 minutes!
How is anyone supposed to solve this if they don't tell us when he won the Hugo?!

You know what?  You CAN'T win 'em all.

Tsk.  I had to give up in the SW corner.  IN A PAST LIFE I might have gotten this, but not today.  This is all the time I have to devote to Fun and Games!  Some kind of RAT, and 87D's entry of "CHECKED" (off)  --you tick things off on your To-Do List-- and of course "singer-songwriter" is a fatal category for me...  So, 4 wrong letters.  Neither the sun nor the MOLE RAT could ARISE for me today.  It's pretty cold, the winds are high, and the clouds are amassed.  

Very clever puzzle concept, ad I really enjoyed sussing the themers out.  I always like to be reminded of "Mr. Hartje" at Florida Southern (later he earned the PhD and returned for the rest of his career.)  He was a wonderful teacher of "The Queen of Sciences," as he called it, and for the first time I really understood what we were doing and why.  It was a revelation!  He urged me to change my major, and maybe it would have been a good thing to do--but this was back in the day when a woman could be a teacher, nurse, or secretary--and I didn't question the "acceptable choices."  (However, I did know every possible way to be confused, and I was a grand math teacher for my special ed students...  LOL)
Finished rather quickly. But can someone explain 32D?

I found this an appropriate Sunday challenge; there were quite a few delightful clues, including those for the theme, which put me in mind of my father who, when I was a kid struggling to multiply and divide fractions, bought me a mathematical encyclopedia that I still have 60 years later‚Ä¶though I still struggle with multiplying and dividing fractions. I thought of my sister, too, who failed geometry in high school, said it wasn‚Äôt going to defeat her, and went on to become a professor of mathematics.
I was kind of expecting someone to claim they had finished this in, say, ten minutes. Took me longer, but not as long as some Sunday puzzles. Not at all familiar with the term REP.

Lovely Sunday puzzle, with just enough ESOTERICA for ADDED COMPLEXITY. There will be DIFFERENCEs OF OPINION on that amount, I'm sure.

Thanks, Emily and Kunal.

Trying to come up with my own...

This puzzle was the perfect amount of [Tr¬∞uble] for me!

(degree of difficulty)
Great job, it was lots of fun (with a little assist)

Is there a different place for comments on the Magazine Spelling Bee?  Noticed in today‚Äôs (1/19/25) puzzle answers that Frank Longo credited himself with 3 pangrams for 9 points when one (piehole) does not contain the letter  N.  His score is actually 27.  I found a third ‚Äú semi-pangram,‚Äù  PHONELINE, which is legitimately probably two words, though spell check doesn‚Äôt correct it. Not to mention about 5 other perfectly nice dictionary words that aren‚Äôt in Frank‚Äôs answers, but that has always been the editor‚Äôs prerogative.
This puzle was POGGERS

I hope today's puzzle will be graded on a CURVE.

Seriously, I had to re-take Algebra II in my senior year of HS, so I never got to Calculus, which is a shame, because I aced Geometry. So 99A was a bit of a stumper, especially as I mis-read the integral symbol as the function symbol. The crosses were very helpful. Umpires crying "foul!" at 103D was my hidden gem of the day.
They said there would be no math.

I always like when you can discern something about the author from clues/themes in the answers. This one had:
Aga Khan
Raita
Assam
Mahabharata
Ginger
Was pretty sure we had an Indian author!
If only "one term" applied to someone else! Black Monday ahead. Otherwise, Emily and Kunal, you can return as often as you wish...

I got stuck in the SE for a bit, and *almost* had to do a lookup, but I left it while I filled in the rest of the puzzle, and suddenly (it always works that way, right?) the rest was a breeze. Weirdly, EXEC is what I was really stumped on for the longest time.
I found it impossible to guess today's Spangram because it's not an actual word. And if it was a word, I wouldn't have spelled it the way it's spelled. What were you thinking?

Ok, so Caitlin‚Äôs column cleared up why I found the theme clues impossible; maths. Ugh. I have dyscalculia, confirmed in my 40‚Äôs when my youngest was ‚Äòdiagnosed ‚Äò. Before that I was just thick, according to every maths teacher I ever had. How times change. 

As I was thrown out of every maths class and was never allowed to take physics or chemistry (see teacher‚Äôs assessment of me above), I have no idea what all the squiggles mean by the theme clues. I tell you, it triggers my PTSD just looking at them. Thank goodness my kids had a smoother ride through the education system.
Anyhoo, the puzzle was good, if I ignore the maths stuff. The Indian based clues were interesting; I love RAITA, but haven‚Äôt come across the chickpea balls before.
Gummy bears and other super sugary stuff on an already sweet dessert fairly turned my stomach, but each to their own.
"Like some parking and poetry"  aaaah, so good!

I enjoyed this puzzle, and didn't stumble with the math, which was nice. My dad and my uncle were math nerds, and did math problems for entertainment. Beyond me for sure.  But the "brush wolves" reminded me of a hike I was on last spring. My dogs and I ran into a coyote with pups on the trail, she chased us for a long while and scared me quite a bit.

Good afternoon from the tiny little corner of SE CT where we will just be getting 1-3" of snow later, after some rain. 
Thanks for the enjoyable Sunday - now I'm craving Indian food!
Had OGEE in there for 69D, but changed the G to a P when filling in 72A: Many humanitarian grps. blythely put in NPO's and went about my business. Flyspecking cost me some time, but I wasn't going to QUIT.
Hope you have HEAT in your home, don't SKID in the snow, and have the STAMINA to outlast the cold snap.
For 92A, did anybody else want to tie a cherry STEM into a knot with their tongue, a la Sherilyn Fenn in "Twin Peaks?" That would be my tribute to David Lynch. Fire walk with me.

Fun puzzle, loved the indian clues, particularly 61D - I went through zeera, haldi, dhania, in my head, then did some crosses to get the aha moment! I should have known, since you can start by cutting onions, garlic and ginger and then decide what you want to make. 

Got stuck forever at the end because (in a double take) I had put JAr instead of JAM in 54A and it took forever to find my error.
I usually do all the Minis for a week at once. Thanks, Christina, for a fun Monday-Sunday run this week!

I think of a DING DONG as a big argument!
I got stuck on TAGSALE, whatever it is?
What is OMS?
Also stuck on "theatrical release" because I assume theatrical means a theatre and a film release would be cinematic. 
I learnt about IMARETS.
No tilde key on my keyboard.
Forgot the meanings of REP and  CANS  in USA.
Forgot the nail polish, though it's been in before. I don't know any nail polish names.
Forgot about the habit of abbreviation for ECOL (should know by now) and SUPE (tried JANNY) and EXEC.
There is a big name in syrup - who knew?

I got so much via the crossers but had to look up the 'famous' people, except Descartes. 
Managed to finish in an hour. Did enjoy it!

Alas, I did not correctly complete this puzzle because I had NpO at 72A (non-profit organization) and do not know a whit about architectural moldings to differentiate between OpEE and OGEE at 69D. It was not an error I could locate because I really thought it was NpO and the crossing was meaningless to me. Kind of a bummer, for them's the breaks.

It's interesting because I see that OGEE has been used I think it was 96 previous times in the NYT crossword, though the last few were a little bit before my time in the puzzles. But I also see that NpO has never been used, which surprises me, I guess. I guess I'll have to learn one new to me word and unlearn an old one. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

I did enjoy the puzzle. The themes were fun. I had a couple other hangups that I was able to work out, but they held me up. From early on, I had sIgnS instead of RISKS at 85A, which made it look like 78D was something starting with ego, which seemed plausible. I finally took out a few things, including signs, and got it. Also had a little difficulty in the Southwest corner, but it was ultimately workoutable, especially once I gave up on back in my day for 67D. üòâ

Also, sorry, I haven't yet read the comments this time, but I'm guessing this may have come up: TAGSALE. That's a new one for me, but it was very gettable on the crosses. I looked it up and see that it's a regional thing for what I know as a garage sale, rummage sale, or yard sale. So interesting all the regionalisms you learn in the puzzle!
One of the worst sundays in a long time
I got the answer, but in my puzzle, "99 Across Workout Routine" did not include the calculus symbol spoken of in Word Play.

Wonderful puzzle for me, as I enjoy the flash that comes when crosses allow me to realize I am thinking of a completely wrong usage.  I can't count how many times that happened to me today.  And, like a previous poster, I nearly did a literal head slap as my face turned red when it dawned on me that 110D was a term I use way too much.
CHEESED off? I saw it, didn‚Äôt believe it, tried it, solved the puzzle. Always learning

Late puzzle find. I've NEVER seen on like this. A Sunday from May 22, 1977 by Maura B. Jacobson with the title... well 'Pi,' but the title was actually just the symbol for pi. Some examples of theme clues and answers: "RAC EHT TUP" PUTTHECARINREVERSE "America and Liberty 0" MISSESNOTHING "After 3d 25¬¢" FOURTHQUARTER And most of the rest of the theme answers, as rendered in Xword Info, just had the clue "See image." But there is a link to the PDF version of that puzzle on that page, which shows those images. For example, as best I can: The clue for 25a was just two check marks with a few spaces between them. And the answer was: SEPARATECHECKS And then - the clue for 30a was 0 (zero) above a long line, and under that line were: B.A. and L.L.D. And the answer was TWODEGREESBELOWZERO And it gets even weirder than that. Don't think I could describe many other of the theme clues as they included multiple symbols. Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/PS?date=5/22/1977&g=108&d=A I'm done. ....

Good one. Regarding TAG SALE Back in 2013 there was a dialect quiz in the NYT; you answered 25 questions about what terms you use for certain things, and it guesses where you live or at least grew up. Things like "do you call this kind of sandwich a hoagie/grinder/sub/footlong" or "do you call this kind of sale a yard sale/tag sale/garage sale", or "is it you all/y'all/youse/yinz". It pegged me properly. If you decide to try it, come back and let us know how it did with you. https://nytimes.com/interactive/2014/upshot/dialect-quiz-map.html FWIW I'm not sure if it asks everyone the same 25 questions, or if there's branching involved.

I'm old and nitpicking, but English is English and words have meaning, even though nowadays people tend to ignore meanings of certain words they use.
If you use a clue Largest organ in the human body, the answer can't be SKIN.
First, the skin is an outer layer that protects the body, it can't necessarily be IN the body it protects.
Second, by that definition, it's an epidermis not an ORGAN. But you know, some universities are like tomato tomato. Whatever.

Mild breezy fun but not completely satisfying. 
The math clues based on math symbols were ok, but some appeared a bit forced - SquaredUp 82-A being the most so. Also 66-A DifferenceOfOpinion - in my humble ‚Äúopinion‚Äù - should have been ‚ÄúDifference In Opinion‚Äù the operator literally being IN the middle of the sentence. Also I interpreted 99-A as the usual ‚Äúroutine‚Äù you do at the gym, ‚Äúcircuiting‚Äù all your usual equipment in order, integrated into a holistic routine, and not a chip board. Felt awkward

Other clues seemed much too trivia-GK based - I am Indian so I got 43-A AIM Arjuna‚Äôs skill and 118-A RAITA but not sure if this would be familiar to the average non-Indian?
Similarly I had ZERO idea about 40-A Strega Nona, read it up in Wiki today for the first time, it‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs common knowledge in the English speaking world ?
15-D Kilimanjaro was a total handout once you get 14-A Skin.
19-A Karo big name in syrup, really ? Never seen it in the NYC area far as I know.
56-A Coyotes? Who calls them Brush wolves ? Do they skulk in the ‚Äúbrushes‚Äù ? Never heard before
21A Utile seems too archaic, never seen that in recent or distant memory.
22A Division of Labor - best fit of the lot and clicked in nicely!
104A Eli I thought was too much of a give away
36A Agee was pure trivia - far as I know Night of the Hunter is famous thanks to Mitchum, otherwise not sure how many today would recall James Agee? It‚Äôs not like he was F Scott Fitzgerald or Hemingway, no disrespect to Agee

Ninas or ninos? Nope, nenes! NPOs? UM NO, NGOs!  IDYLS? Srsly?

The theme entries were fairly straightforward and easy to figure out, but some of the crossing entries CHEESED me off a bit. Also, the thought of gummi bears and chocolate chips on yogurt, frozen or otherwise, is just disgusting.
Pretty good one.  Got stumped, so I peeked at the answer and there it was.  Why does it always have to be spelling?

I loved stuff like MOLE RAT. Once the Bronx Zoo had an exhibit of ‚ÄúNaked Mole Rats‚Äù üêÄ and my husband made a big joke of it. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

All the Math puns were good. Very fun. At first I wasn‚Äôt sure what I was doing as I hadn‚Äôt seen the puzzle title but it was a great thing to wander into.

Or maybe it‚Äôs honey ginger. I think they‚Äôre called Throat Coat and maybe from Thrive market.

I had 8 years of obligatory math classes in primary school and high school - I understood very little and hated it all, even the stuff I did understand. I was a very good student in general, and I aced almost all of my courses, but math was my nemesis. I could not see how any of it would be of any use to me in practice, except the most basic stuff. And sure enough, beyond occasionally having to be able to add or subtract some numbers, or to understand percentages and the decimal system, I have never needed to know any math in my quite successful and fulfilling life. @Richard Landster 

The following is intended to be helpful to you (and anyone else who had trouble with these words)  moving forward, and not a criticism of your comment, which is valid for your solving experience.  Please don't take it as a putdown.

IMARET(S) is a very common crossword answer, due to its friendly letters.  It has appeared 96 times in the singular, and 18 more in the plural.  Both forms showed up in 2024. Obscure in real life, yes, but you should put that in your back pocket because it'll appear again.  

As for NENES, not slang, as Rita says, but just informal.  If you have dealt with Hispanic parents in your travels, as I have, you'll find it to be very commonly used.  And of the 23 times in the Modern Era (out of 51 total), NENES in the plural has always been clued to Spanish babies, and never to Hawaiian geese.  (Before that, there was a fairly even split.  I imagine it was probably not a correct plural, so it was abandoned at some point.)

ASSAM is a tea- and silk-producing state of Northern India that has appeared 218 times.  Again, this word is frequently used because of its common letters, so whenever you see a five-letter answer clued as an Indian state, ASSAM's your guy.  The last one that was different, DELHI, was in 2001.
@Richard Landster And AYO may be obscure to you, but not to the folks who hand out Emmy, SAG, and Golden Globe Awards.

@G 

I had to select that I say aunt, in the Boston Manor, when I think of general aunts. However, when I talk about my own aunt, I call her aunt in the manner of a tiny insect. I've actually noticed this before about myself and think it's odd, so I was surprised to see the question in the quiz. Seems to me I'm not alone in the world!  üòâ

Fun fact, well, it starts off not so fun, my aunt Pat died in March and she was quite beloved to me. But the fun fact is that when we had to clean out her house, I found this little birthday card I made her probably when I was 10... The outside reads, "To a great ant!" And I drew a little picture of an ant on the outside. I mean it's a terrible picture I'm still better at puns than I am drying, but it's hilarious. 

And just in case you think I might have just been mistaken, on the inside I correctly addressed her as Aunt Pat and wished her such a happy birthday because and told her she's the best aunt ever.

All of which is quite true.

I was so amazed and touched that she had it all this time and not even like totally buried. Anyhow. Aunt, aunt
